data.title: Keeping the faith in We Are the Body
data.meta_description: How far would you go for what you believe?
data.text:

Article content

How far would you go for what you believe?

That’s the question that hangs over the characters of We Are the Body, Red Deer playwright Andrew Kooman’s thoughtful, harrowing drama that explores the traumas inflicted upon a group of Romanian Christians imprisoned during the Communist era for their beliefs.

Article content

We Are the Body, inspired by the writing of Richard Wurmbrand, tells the story of how a few Christian prisoners keep hope alive by communicating, while in solitary confinement, via Morse code.

There’s Richard (Tim Bratton), who taps out sermons, Elsie (Heather Pattengale) and Micah (John McIver), each of whom tap away at each other’s loneliness and isolation, hoping to generate enough hope that they survive the inhumane treatment of their captors.

It all has the ring of authentic truth to it, so when Pattengale’s Elsie is asked to provide names and addresses of fellow Christian travellers by a sadistic prison guard Petre (also McIver), and basically spits in his face, it feels real — real dark.

If We Are the Body was a colour spectrum instead of play — like one of those paint displays at your local Home Depot — it would start on grey and end on black.

There’s no effervescent neon green or orange in sight for a thousand miles of this bleak, dimly lit world, and to the credit of each of the cast, they each turn in powerful performances conveying the anguish of Kooman’s Romanian Gulag nightmare.

Partly, that’s because of Kooman’s imaginative structure, which bounces us around in time and place — we get snatches of the characters’ lives in the outside world, such Elsie’s life in Bucharest before her arrest, where she distributes Bibles on the down low, at the risk of being found out by the aggressive, sadistic Soviet overlords who have descended upon the so-called breadbasket of Eastern Europe and ravaged it like those pine beetles do to the Western Canada woods in a drought.

Pattengale, a regular in Rosebud productions, bestows a kind of spiritual ferocity on Elsie, who goes through nine kinds of hell. Bratton’s Richard is more restrained — he’s a deeply spiritual man who seems determined not to give his captors the satisfaction of seeing him in anguish. As both Micah and the guard Petre, McIver delivers a strong, believable performance.

Director Stephen Waldschmidt, who also designed the simple but symbolic set, keeps the story moving, but it feels as if there’s a long stretch that stays stuck on more or less the same emotional note — namely the resilience of the Christian captives who rely upon their faith in God to resist the agony their physical and spiritual selves are being put through.

Towards the conclusion, when Richard puts it all into words — that each of them are the Body of Christ, and that their suffering is a kind of commitment to God — a little light begins to shine in on the gloom. But it’s still more or less a made-in-Eastern-Europe brand of bulb doing the illuminating, and we all know how well that worked out.

We Are the Body

at the Pumphouse through May 23
